title: Thursday, 9th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Hi! Hello. Good morning. Welcome. Hey.

BE11:04am

So. Busy day for corporate.

BE11:04am

Including Burberry numbers, of course, which as always has been an excuse for business sections to run pictures of models.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

We swim against the tide here, though, so I'm going to use these pixels to give a boost to an upstart brand.

BE11:05am

It's called Burberrylied.

BE11:05am

And it seems really popular in China.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

BE11:06am

Sometimes goes by the name Burberryity. And, yeah, really, really really popular.

BE11:06am

11:06 am
BE11:06am

There are a few thousand listings on a website I won't name, all offering speedy UK delivery and payment by Visa or Mastercard.

BE11:06am

BE11:07am

Many also offering Paypal, which I'm fairly sure is against Paypal's T&Cs.

11:06 am
BE11:07am

BE11:07am

.... so if you're bereft that Burberry has sold out of its mid-length technical cotton double gun flap trench ....

BE11:07am

11:07 am
BE11:07am

.... how about a Burberrylied?

BE11:07am

BE11:07am

This is the bind luxury goods finds itself in, of course. And it's a bind Burberry's been in several times in the past.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

You can try to hit the "accessible luxury" side of things, which is a good way to hit numbers but tends to have consequences for brand value ...

BE11:08am

.... Not least because mass market appeal puts your label into the minds of folk who are fine with buying stuff from Chinese websites.

BE11:09am

So, Burberry's taking the only road that remains available. It's going higher end.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

The idea, I guess, is to try and move it out of accessible luxury and into some superstrata realm of tiny volumes for select types, and not even the Chinese will find a reason to do knockoffs.

BE11:11am

The other part of today's warning -- yeah, it's a warning -- is an upgrade of distribution.

BE11:11am

Another one.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

You'll remember Angela Ahrendts had logistics upgrades and stuff at the centre of her plan.

BE11:12am

Well ............. hey, here we go again.

BE11:12am

(@Burberry Ioffer you no clues, sorry.)

11:12 am
BE11:12am

And it's going to take two years.

BE11:13am

This was all somewhat flagged. It was fairly obvious that a reset would be the first thing Marco Gobbetti had to do.

BE11:14am

Don't think anyone expected 10-15% off consensus for the next few years though, which is what we've got.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Morgan Stanley incoming.

BE11:14am

Change is positive, and a expectation reset is a sensible move, we think. Burberry has been going through a period of unprecedented change, with several new management and design appointments, suggesting the start of a brand new chapter for this company. With the market looking for "the next Gucci story", we think that the successful implementation of this (ambitious) repositioning strategy could be a very attractive medium-term proposition. A reset of expectations to a more realistic "medium-term path to recovery" was also a sensible move by the incoming executive team, we think.

BE11:14am

We have some concerns, though: i) Creative leadership. While the brand / product repositioning is a core part of the new strategy, the company now lacks a Creative Director (post announcement of Christopher Bailey's imminent exit). ii) Competitive environment. Leather goods is an extremely competitive segment with very few success stories of product diversification, implying a riskier growth equation. iii) Timing. We think the market might find that too much patience is required to get to a recovery path (with the first concrete signs not expected until FY21e).

11:14 am
BE11:14am

We lower our price target by -4% to GBp 16.76 (implying a 20x 2018e P/E). While we factor in a c.15% downgrade p.a. in FY19-21, we then assume a progressive top-line pick-up (to mid single digit organic growth – below guidance) and some margin recovery (to 18.9% by 2023e). All in all, our long-term forecasts more or less converge with our previous estimates, and our DCF valuation points to a -4% reduction in our valuation to GBp 16.76 (our new PT). This implies c.-15% downside from current trading levels and a 2018e cal. P/E of 20x, below the luxury sector average of 25x (and reflecting the depressed medium-term margin outlook).

BE11:15am

And Merrill, which downgrades .......

BE11:15am

We see 14% downside risk to consensus 2020 EPS. Premium valuation already discounts optimistic view on brand turnaround, of which visibility is still limited. Move to U/P.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

And SocGen.

BE11:15am

Ongoing retrenchment is unlikely to boost sales growth above that of peers, as targeted (with Burberry having just one brand, c.20% fewer SKUs, a 4-5% capex/sales ratio vs the sector's 5.5-6.0%, no selling space growth, a halt in product diversification, and a low or no price-mix impact). 2) Margin-wise, the opex cut is only half that needed to reach the peer average and is offset by reinvestments, reflecting an opex floor that mitigates the low capital intensity. This should reduce market EPS estimates by up to a double digit percentage, in our view.

BE11:15am

[W]e consider that Burberry is the most underinvested brand in the sector, with a invested capital base/sales of 32% vs the sector average of 91%. The new plan provides for massive reinvestment, a good strategy, but, in our view, with two issues: it will take over two years to show an effect, and there is considerable uncertainty as to where the extra capex will be spent (upstream integration), given the already large store network.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

(I'll be quite surprised if the Lex note today isn't headlined "Retrench", by the way.)

(Also note that the shares have halved since the Carphone merger, which is quite something.)

Generics warning and a delay to generic Advair.

Here's Citi.

BE11:26am

News that Hikma is in
dispute with FDA over gAdvair will not help sentiment; we continue to assume 2019 is the earliest one might see a potential launch. The balance sheet is strong (net debt/EBITDA 1x – firepower $1.0-1.5bn) with options being considered including the acquisition of injectable assets, the pursuit of JV opportunities as it relates to US Generics, MENA/frontier market acquisitions, and as a last resort buybacks ($500m buyback at a Kd of 3% implies 2018-20e EPS upside of 9-12%). While sentiment is poor, we think it too early to revisit the shares given ongoing gAdvair uncertainty, lack of broader pipeline visibility, and consensus for FY18 still looking optimistic.

BE11:27am

Implications — Revenue guidance $2bn CER (Citi forecasting -2% FX headwind) and expectations for Branded/Injectable Generics reiterated – see page 2. US Generics revenue guidance –3% to $600m with EBIT margin reduced from 5% to “low single digit” ($6-24m versus $30m previously). We expect consensus adjusted EBIT/EPS to move towards $365m and $0.97 (implies growth of -11% and -15%). While further cost savings are being sought Injectables/US Generics could post declining EBIT in 2018, especially as Injectable margins of 39% are expected to normalise to low-30s. Citi 15-20% below consensus EPS in 2018e.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

And Numis, knife catching.

BE11:28am

Our forecasts for FY17 are unchanged, and FY18 are now in line with consensus. The shares trade on 12x P/E with a high FCF yield (8%) becoming increasingly appealing. We believe the weakness this morning is overdone and upgrade to Buy for a company with diverse growth drivers, and excellent long-term prospects through organic growth and M&A.

BE11:30am

In terms of sector, GSK gets some support on the Advair news, though given it's still sword of Damocles stuff you'd be silly to put too much of a value on the Advair franchise.

Q3 revenues and EBITDA are both 3-4% ahead of consensus1. We estimate ~40% the revenue beat and ~65% of the EBITDA beat are attributable to one-off hurricane related spend (Government and Enterprise). Revenues are further supported by strong low margin hardware sales ($4m Maritime and $11m IFC installs). Going forward management note: (1) ex-US government will be lower due to a “material reduction in exceptional operational revenues which had been received since Q3'15”, JPMe $10m pa impact; (2) government faces a tough Q4 owing to a $15m one-off in the y/y comparable; and (3) the 2018E aviation margin is expected ~40% vs. consensus 48%. Updating for Q3, 2017E estimates are broadly unchanged, 2018E revenues and EBITDA fall 2% and 3% respectively, and mid-term cuts are mid-single-digit.

And Morgan Stanley, off the conference call .....

(2) Aviation EBITDA margins will continue to be impacted by efforts to build market share in inflight connectivity. Initial revenues are expected to be low margin installation, rather than higher margin airtime revenues.

Uncertainty surrounding mobile is likely to persist, however Carphone retains a high degree of flexibility to deal with the challenges it faces. Valuation in our view is looking increasingly attractive with recent share price weakness overdone and risk/reward on the upside. We move to BUY from Hold.

All to play for in H2, but FY forecasts are achievable in our view. Stripping out FY17’s one-offs, our FY18e forecasts imply 7% underlying PBT growth in H2. Although some may view this as optimistic/unrealistic, a stable performance in electricals and recovery of lost ground in mobile (which already saw a £25m hit to profits in 2H17 from weak trading) would see forecasts being achieved.

BE11:42am

Recent weakness driven by fears of further material downgrades, which are misplaced in our view. Valuation (5.8x CY18e PE, 7.3% dividend yield) looks increasingly attractive, concerns over mobile notwithstanding. For example, we estimate that on an ex-Carphone basis, the shares trade on less than 7.5x CY18e earnings. As earnings show signs of stabilisation on an underlying basis (i.e. PBT of c. £400m, EPS of 26-27p), the risk/reward balance now lies on the upside in our view. We retain our 185p DCF/SoTP-derived TP and upgrade to BUY.

Arrow has purchased £155m (FY forecast £233m) so far this year driving an increase in the 120-month ERC to £1,690m (FY forecast £1,545m). The Group continues to see attractive opportunities across its core markets, giving management continued confidence in its “ability to meet earnings expectations for the year, deliver a medium-term underlying ROE percentage in mid-twenties, highteens EPS growth and a progressive dividend policy”.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

This is James Hamilton.

BE11:49am

Key reasons to own Arrow: Arrow is a high margin, high growth specialist in an industry that lends itself to natural monopoly status as enhancing returns is dependent on proprietary data and analytics that can't be replicated. With debt purchase in its infancy in many of Arrow's markets and unsecured debt having consistently grown
at a multiple of GDP we see Arrow as operating in a growth industry where it is gaining market share. With its customers paying just £25 per month they are already in recession, making the business less economically sensitive. Unlike a bank that may have an upside of 1% on a mortgage and a downside of 100%. Arrow often has an upside of 1,000% and a downside of 100%. Arrow is increasingly a very specialist noncapital
intensive Asset Management business. Unlike most asset managers because of its data and analytics Arrow faces less competition in a specialist market segment where passive funds cannot operate and commodity capital needs a partner. The group's data and analytics allow Arrow to enhance returns so that a bank can sell a portfolio that it could not make an economic profit from and Arrow can substantially enhance the returns, so much so that Arrow has just reported a 33% ROE.

Headline results. Reported EBIT was £1.26bn (3% below consensus). The miss appears to be in the UK electricity and gas transmission businesses (6% and 13% below consensus respectively), seemingly driven by lower base allowances and higher controllable costs. Reported EPS was 18.5p (including adverse timing effect of 1.9p), which was 5% below consensus. In addition to the miss at the EPS level, contributions from JVs also came in lower than expected (£75m vs. consensus of £109m).

Continued growth in US Regulated business. NG reported 6M EBIT of £433m in its US regulated business. The company is in ongoing discussions with the US regulator over the Niagara Mohawk rate case, and is confident of reaching a reasonable settlement soon, with new rates coming into effect by April 2018. In addition, NG is due to submit rate files for its Massachusetts Gas and Rhode Island Electric and Gas utilities later this month. New rates for Rhode Island Electric and Gas would be expected to come into effect by September 2018, and for Massachusetts Gas by October 2018. With these measures, in the US, NG aims to achieve 90% of the average allowed returns in 2017/18.

Capex remains on track for FY guidance. 6M group capex was £2bn, up 4% at constant currency. Of this, over half (£1.1bn) was invested into the US regulated business, and £672m into its UK electricity and gas transmission businesses. We highlight that NG remains on track to achieve its 2017/18 capex guidance of over £4bn (equally split between UK and US).

Dividend growth continues. The company also announced an interim dividend of 15.49p/share, which represents a 2.1% increase above last year's interim dividend.

FY guidance re-iterated. NG confirmed that it remains confident on delivering FY17/18 guidance. However, it highlighted that it expects financial performance to be significantly weighted to the second half, due to the seasonality of US regulated profits. Over the medium term, NG aims to grow its asset base 5-7%.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Yes, @Boncoeur. All right! You want yield curve, I'll give you yield curve.

BE12:04pm

Though YMMV ...... Natixis's Rene Defossez has a bit about US Treasuries in his strategy daily today.

BE12:04pm

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Since the start of the year, the slope of the 2Y-10Y segment of the US Treasury curve has flattened from 125bp to 67bp. The 30Y-10Y spread has
charted a more jagged trajectory, but it has also flattened, down from 60bp to 45bp.
That there should be a flattening of the US yield curve during a monetary tightening cycle is not in the least abnormal per se: the sensitivity of bond
yields to key policy rates diminishes as maturity increases. However, there are at least three factors suggesting that the yield curve might have behaved differently:
1. The Federal Reserve is proceeding very gingerly in raising the Fed Funds rate: just four hikes in the space of two years (with a long-run
objective that is rather low at 2.75%), whereas during the previous monetary tightening (from 2004 to 2006), there were at least four hikes
each year.
2. Since the crisis, monetary policy consists of both standard measures and non-standard measures. When the Fed Funds rate reached a floor (at end 2008), the Federal Reserve embarked on an asset purchase programme, that was followed by two others. The central bank is about to initiate a balance sheet shrink that, all other things being equal, should lead to a steepening of the yield curve.
3. The US government is expected to implement pro-growth fiscal measures.

BE12:06pm

The first reason why the US yield curve did not steepen this year is that it had already steepened “by anticipation” in 2016. Donald Trump’s victory in the presidential election nourished hopes that a deliberately pro-growth economic policy would be pursued by the new administrating, featuring notably tax cuts, infrastructure spending, etc. The market expected that, to a large extent, election promises would be implemented rapidly. Before these elections, the 2Y-10Y slope was around 80bp. In next to no time, it steepened to 135bp in the wake of these elections. However, gradually, it dawned on investors that Donald Trump’s capacity to deliver good on these promises was limited, as a result of which the yield curve flattened anew, so that by mid-2017 it was back at its levels of August 2016.
The second reason was that Donald Trump’s policies were supposed to be inflationary, pushing up growth above its potential, as they involved
toughening up the country’s trade policy (increase in custom tariffs, notably on products imported from China and Mexico, revision of certain free-trade agreements) and immigration policy. On these fronts also, next to nothing has been achieved. As a result, breakeven inflation for the 10-year TIPS,
which rose sharply between September 2016 and January 2017, is now lower than it was at the start of the year (1.88% vs. 2.07%). The behaviour of
breakeven inflation rates is all the more surprising given that one of their main determinants is the change in crude oil prices, and these have risen by
more than $13/bbl since the elections.
The third reason is that, currently, there is a dearth of very high quality paper at global level. US TNotes remain a first-rate asset, not just because of the robustness of US fundamentals, but also because of the significant market depth. This means notably that foreign investors could step in and replace the Federal Reserve in buying US Treasuries.

BE12:07pm

More recently, it is the announcement by the US Treasury that the increase in issuance would be concentrated at 2, 3 and 5 years and the fact that the long-end of the curve elicits little investor enthusiasm that largely explain the major flattening observed in recent sessions, as a result of which the 10Y- 2Y spread is at its lowest since the crisis.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

In short, the normalisation of monetary policy combined with a deliberately pro-growth economic policy by the Trump administration was supposed to lead to a steepening of the US yield curve. This did unfold, but far too prematurely, on anticipation of a change in economic policy that never happened.
More recently, the Treasury announcement led to an even more pronounced flattening of the curve.
The question now is whether there is a new conundrum in the making whereby, as between 2004 and 2006, the sensitivity of long interest rates to changes in monetary policy would be very slight or whether last year’s “false start” will be followed by a new but rather longer-lasting steepening of the curve, brought about by the restoration of term premiums.

BE12:09pm

Look, there's quite a lot more of this. They're going for a steepening of the 2Y-10Y segment because "inflation premiums priced into interest rates should settle more comfortably at their long-run levels."
